awd_titl_txt: University of Alaska Fairbanks/Sikuliaq Oceanographic Instrumentation - 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the Academic Research Fleet (ARF) fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. The ship was delivered in 2014 and has completed six years of funded operations. UAF requests funds to purchase and install Oceanographic Instrumentation that would be custom engineered to enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2020, during the pandemic-shortened season, Sikuliaq completed 134 days 124 (93%) of which were for NSF. In 2021, the vessel is scheduled to sail 220 days with 124 (56%) days of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation.
1)	Solar Radiometers	$25,335	
2)	Optical Fluorometers	$56,580	
3)	EK80 Acquisition Computer	$7,700	
4)	Science Kiosk Computers	$7,228	
							$96,843	
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Radiometers

We purchased two sets of Kipp&Zonen smart pyranometers and pyrgeometers to continuously measure short- and long-wave infra-red (IR) radiation. Measuring solar irradiance and atmospheric longwave downward radiation is essential in determining the earth’s surface energy budget. This data is important for air-sea flux and climate studies. Given Sikuliaq’s regular operations in the remote Arctic, as well as the accelerated warming in the region, it is critical that Sikuliaq collect accurate radiometer measurements.

The sensors were ordered in spring 2021 and received in the summer. Marine tech Carmen Greto configured two Raspberry PIs to acquire data from the sensors over an industrial communication protocol called Modbus. The data sentences are timestamped and broadcast via UDP over the Data network, which are then logged and used for displays. During the winter 2022 maintenance period, Carmen removed the old Eppley radiometers from the platform above the Science Control Room (SCR). He mounted the new sensors side-by-side, each housed in a ventilation unit. The cables run down to the LAN rack inside the SCR, where the PI cluster and DC power supplies are located. The new radiometers have been up and running, collecting data since February.

Fluorometers

We purchased four WetLabs ECO-Triplet optical sensors from Seabird Scientific in spring 2021. The Triplet is a special-order, three-channel instrument available in a user-defined configuration. It addresses the need for multiple simultaneous scattering and fluorescence measurements in a single device. All four of our Triplets have been configured the same, to measure fluorescence of Chlorophyll and Colored Dissolved Organic Matter (CDOM), and red scattering at 650 nanometers. We have been deploying them on Sikuliaq since last fall for two different applications – plumbed into the ship’s underway surface seawater flow-through system, and mounted on the ship’s CTD rosette for vertical hydrographic profiles.

EK80 Processing Unit

The computer was installed during shipyard this past winter. As part of the software upgrade, we needed to do a set of target strength (TS) calibrations, which we try and do annually anyways. Rather than schlep all the way up to Port Madison in Puget Sound, we decided to try and do it in the Swan Island Basin, right next to the Vigor shipyard, on the Willamette River in Portland, Oregon. We were able to calibrate all five split-beam transducers (18, 38, 70, 120, 200 kHz) with CW signals at a pulse length of 1.024 ms, in addition to the 38 and 120 kHz at 0.0512 ms, for a total of 7 calibrations. We use a 38.1 mm tungsten carbide sphere for all of the transducers, with the exception of the 18 kHz, it’s necessary to use the larger 64 mm copper sphere. Sikuliaq is the first ship to do an EK80 calibration in this location as far as I’m aware.


Last Modified: 05/20/2022
Modified by: Ethan H Roth
